<p><strong>As digitization has risen</strong> on the executive agenda, cybersecurity skills and processes in most companies have also advanced, though at a slower pace. But <a href="/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/the-internet-of-things-the-value-of-digitizing-the-physical-world">rapid growth in the Internet of Things</a> (IoT) is changing the game. Cybersecurity is more relevant and challenging than ever, and companies need to build capabilities in this area—quickly.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor-signup mck-o-sm-left-span mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-signup"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-7 DisruptorSignUp_mck-c-disruptor-signup__heading__JR4i0"><div>Stay current on your favorite topics</div></h2></div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--align-left"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/user-registration/register-mvc" class="mdc-c-button___U4iY2_990311c mdc-c-button--primary___Ed-lT_990311c mdc-c-button--size-large___jwpUy_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Subscribe</span></a></div></div>
<p>IoT holds great potential to help companies improve their products and services or increase production efficiency by harnessing sensors and actuators that seamlessly connect objects to computing systems. No wonder, then, that many companies are bringing more and more devices, products, or production systems online. Conventional estimates suggest we could reach 20 billion to 30 billion connected devices globally by 2020, up from 10 billion to 15 billion devices in 2015. However, as devices proliferate, the security risks will increase sharply. Historically, risking the confidentiality and integrity of information was the prime concern compared with any risk regarding availability. In the IoT world, lack of availability of key plants or—even worse—tampering with a customer product becomes the dominating risk. How can CEOs and senior executives hedge against that threat?</p>
<h2>The challenge of cybersecurity in the Internet of Things</h2>
<p>With the IoT, security challenges move from a company’s traditional IT infrastructure into its connected products in the field. And these challenges remain an issue through the entire product life cycle, long after products have been sold. What’s more, industrial IoT, or Industry 4.0, means that security becomes <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/how-to-achieve-and-sustain-the-impact-of-digital-manufacturing-at-scale">a pervasive issue in production</a> as well. Cyberthreats in the world of IoT can have consequences beyond compromised customer privacy. Critical equipment, such as pacemakers and entire manufacturing plants, is now vulnerable—meaning that customer health and a company’s total production capability are at risk.</p>
<p>The sheer number of cybersecurity attack vectors increases dramatically as ever more “things” are connected. Earlier, a large corporate network might have somewhere between 50,000 and 500,000 endpoints; with the IoT, we are talking about millions or tens of millions of endpoints. Unfortunately, many of these consist of legacy devices with inadequate security, or no security at all.</p>
<p>This added complexity makes the IoT a more difficult security environment for companies to manage. Those that succeed, though, could use strong cybersecurity to differentiate themselves in many industries.</p>
<p>To explore views on the relevance of and companies’ preparedness for IoT security, McKinsey conducted a multinational expert survey with 400 managers from Germany, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States. The results indicate a yawning gap between perceived priority and the level of preparedness:</p>
<ul class="bulletList">
    <li>Of the IoT-involved experts surveyed, 75 percent say that IoT security is either important or very important, and that its relevance will increase. But only 16 percent say their company is well prepared for the challenge (Exhibit 1). The survey also indicated that low preparedness is often linked to insufficient budget allocated to IoT cybersecurity.</li>
    <li>Our interviews revealed that companies are ill prepared at every step of the IoT security action chain (predict, prevent, detect, react). Especially weak are prediction capabilities; 16 percent feel well prepared, compared with 24 to 28 percent on prevent, detect, and react.</li>
    <li>More than one-third of companies lack a cybersecurity strategy that also covers the IoT. The rest have some sort of strategy but many report struggling to implement it.</li>
</ul>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/featured%20insights/internet%20of%20things/our%20insights/six%20ways%20ceos%20can%20promote%20cybersecurity%20in%20the%20iot%20age/svgz-six-ways-ceos-can-promote-cybersecurity-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="IoT security is perceived as a priority by 75 percent of experts, but only 16 percent say their company is well prepared." src="/~/media/mckinsey/featured%20insights/internet%20of%20things/our%20insights/six%20ways%20ceos%20can%20promote%20cybersecurity%20in%20the%20iot%20age/svgz-six-ways-ceos-can-promote-cybersecurity-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Why haven’t companies made progress on cybersecurity implementation, given the perceived risk? Our survey indicated a few factors:</p>
<ul class="bulletList">
    <li><em>Lack of prioritization.</em> In general, there isn’t an “act now” mentality among senior management. Few leaders have made the business case for a specific IoT security strategy that would, in turn, make the effort a priority and trigger the allocation of sufficient resources.</li>
    <li><em>Unclear responsibility.</em> There needs to be a holistic cybersecurity concept for the entire IoT stack, but often no single player feels responsible for creating it. First, there is the question of whether initial responsibility lies with product makers or with suppliers. And within organizations, it’s proved difficult to determine which unit (IT security, production, product development, or customer service) should take the lead. Product or plant managers often do not have cybersecurity expertise, while corporate IT does not have sufficient access to product teams or the industrial control systems “behind the fence.”</li>
    <li><em>Lack of standards and technical skills.</em> There are some industry working groups, but IoT security standards are still largely nonexistent. Even if there were standards in place, the technical competence to implement them—a mix of operational technology and IT security knowledge—is in short supply.</li>
</ul>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Would you like to learn more about how we help clients understand the <a href="/featured-insights/internet-of-things/how-we-help-clients">Internet of Things</a>?</div></h3></div></header></div></div></div>
<p>With the advent of the IoT, cybersecurity affects the entire business model. Adequately addressing the threat means bringing together several business perspectives, including the market, the customer, production, and IT. And the CEO is often the only leader with the authority to make cybersecurity a priority across all these areas.</p>
<h2>Six recommendations for CEOs</h2>
<p>Although there is no single winning approach for tackling <a href="/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/cybersecurity-for-the-iot-how-trust-can-unlock-value">cybersecurity in the IoT</a>, six recommendations can guide senior executives. Three concern strategic lenses for thinking about IoT security, and the other three are actions to help CEOs and other leaders set their organizations up for success.</p>
<h3>1. Understand what IoT security will mean for your industry and business model</h3>
<p>Across all industries, a certain minimum level of IoT security will be required as a matter of “hygiene.” The recent WannaCry attack largely compromised organizations with legacy operating systems that had not been patched appropriately. Simple patch management—a matter of adequate IT management, not sophisticated cyberdefense—should be routine, not something customers pay a price premium for.</p>
<p>However, we think there is potential for treating security as more than just hygiene. In the past decade, many companies saw IT evolve from a cost center to a source of real differentiation, driving customer satisfaction and willingness to pay. A similar change could lie ahead for IoT security, and in an increasing number of industries, we are already witnessing it today. One example is the physical security industry. Door-lock companies can already today demand a price premium for products with especially strong cybersecurity features, as cybersecurity can make or break the main function of the product.</p>
<p>Effective IoT security solutions consider an organization’s business model, where it lies in the value chain, and the industry structures in which it operates (see sidebar, “More trust, less downtime: Examples of the role and relevance of IoT security by industry”).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>More trust, less downtime: Examples of the role and relevance of IoT security by industry</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>The goal of an Internet of Things (IoT) security strategy varies by industry and company type. Industries differ in their approach, depending on many factors, such as the role of cybersecurity in differentiating the product, the supply-chain structure and incentives, and the level of maturity reached to date. A few examples illustrate this:</p>
<ul class="bulletList">
    <li>For an energy utility, IoT security is mostly a production play, as it will mean dealing with a large installed base of legacy production systems that were never designed to be connected and, in turn, were not designed with defense against cyberattacks in mind. What is more, legacy systems have little additional capacity (for example, computing performance and memory) that could be used for added security measures, and they are often not accessible in the field. To reap the huge benefits from connecting these systems nonetheless, targeted countermeasures need to be taken. Process-industry players in particular have leveraged their innate strength in industrial safety for creating new processes and safety measures, creating redundancy, and “sandboxing” key systems to avoid entire system failure. Challenges for industrials lie in the lack of cybersecurity expertise of many component suppliers and the lack of standardization incentives for many integrators.</li>
    <li>For <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/shifting-gears-in-cybersecurity-for-connected-cars">automotive OEMs</a>, IoT security is also a product play and will become the new quality management for the era of connected cars. OEMs are facing unique challenges given the increasing complexity of their product: a modern car includes between 30 and 100 electronic control units (ECUs) and hundreds of millions lines of code—a level of complexity at which even the best programmers cannot avoid vulnerabilities. What’s more, the automotive industry has one of the most fragmented supply chains. The 30 to 100 ECUs could easily be sourced from more than 20 different suppliers, creating additional complexity. Thus, a holistic concept is needed to address two aspects. First, cybersecurity needs to be embedded in the design and development of the product, as well as in the maintenance and response architecture. Second, OEMs must work closely in their ecosystem—for example, with other industry players and regulatory bodies to set up standards, and with the end users who are directly involved in protecting their cars (such as by keeping software updated). However, solutions will have to scale well and be cost effective, as OEMs have to contend with users’ limited willingness to pay for added cybersecurity.</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>CEOs must understand the role and relevance of IoT security in their industries and how to monetize solutions in alignment with their business model. A thorough understanding of what IoT security means for a company cannot end at the strategic level, though. CEOs need to be aware of the main points of vulnerability. Typically, an overview of the top attack scenarios for a specific company and an understanding of attackers and their motivations will be a good base for further strategy development and budget allocations. Security investments must be targeted according to the risk most detrimental to the specific business or industry.</p>
<h3>2. Set up clear roles and responsibilities for IoT security along your supply chain</h3>
<p>IoT requires a holistic cybersecurity concept that extends across the entire IoT stack—all layers of the application, communication, and sensors. Of course, each layer needs to be secured, but companies also need to prepare for cross-layer threats (Exhibit 2).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/featured%20insights/internet%20of%20things/our%20insights/six%20ways%20ceos%20can%20promote%20cybersecurity%20in%20the%20iot%20age/svgz-six-ways-ceos-can-promote-cybersecurity-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="IoT security requires an integrated concept with security solutions for each layer of the loT stack and for cross-layer threats." src="/~/media/mckinsey/featured%20insights/internet%20of%20things/our%20insights/six%20ways%20ceos%20can%20promote%20cybersecurity%20in%20the%20iot%20age/svgz-six-ways-ceos-can-promote-cybersecurity-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>This will require a strategic dialogue with upstream and downstream business partners, whether suppliers or customers, to sort out responsibilities for security along the entire supply chain. A starting point for this discussion should be identifying the weakest links in the holistic model; from an attacker’s point of view, these will be targeted first to harm the entire chain. Who then takes on which role should depend on who has the competence and who has the incentives, which might include a monetization model. Industry players active in each part of the IoT stack bring certain advantages they can build on to provide an integrated solution:</p>
<ul class="bulletList">
    <li>Device and <a href="/industries/semiconductors/our-insights/security-in-the-internet-of-things">semiconductor manufacturers</a> active at the lower level of the stack can build on their design capabilities of low-level (hardware) security as an advantage for designing higher (software) security.</li>
    <li>Network equipment manufacturers profit from the fact that many key competencies in transport-layer security design are applicable to the application layer. Beyond that, they can build on their hardware design capabilities to offer an integrated solution.</li>
    <li>Application designers can leverage their control of application interfaces or customer access as an advantage in defining low-level architectures.</li>
</ul>
<h3>3. Engage in strategic conversations with your regulator and collaborate with other industry players</h3>
<p>A company’s cybersecurity creates externalities that go far beyond the effects on the company’s performance itself and thus needs to be tackled across the classic government–business divide. Most current cybersecurity standards fall short because they are neither industry specific nor detailed enough, and they neglect most layers of the IoT stack, including production and product development. Regulators will eventually step in to address this gap, and companies need to get involved in the discussion, or set the tone.</p>
<p>Industry leaders can shape these structures by bringing together key players to establish IoT security standards for their industry. Partnerships with other players, including competitors, can also lead to a mutually beneficial pooling of resources beyond official industry standards. In the banking sector, for instance, one company got several competitors together to set up “shared assessments” to evaluate security technology vendors, resulting in enormous efficiency gains for both the banks and their suppliers. Another example from the sector is FS-ISAC, an information community through which competing banks share information on security weaknesses, attacks, and successful countermeasures.</p>
<h3>4. Conceive of cybersecurity as a priority for the entire product life cycle, and develop relevant skills to achieve it</h3>
<p>Security needs to be part of the entire product life cycle, from product design to the development process, and continuing each day of the product’s use. Fundamental to the security of products in the field is “security by design” in the product-development stage. It’s also crucial to ensure security during the production or manufacturing process, given the role of Industry 4.0 in driving the proliferation of IoT on shop floors and in other production settings. Last, a concept is required for securing products after they have been sold. To this end, companies need a strategy to deliver security patches to products in the field, for example, via over-the-air update capabilities.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="Quarterly-2015_web_executivesIOT_525434225_1536_Original" src="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/mckinsey%20digital/our%20insights/an%20executives%20guide%20to%20the%20internet%20of%20things/quarterly%202015_web_executivesiot_525434225_1536_original.jpg?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>An executive’s guide to the Internet of Things</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/an-executives-guide-to-the-internet-of-things" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Read the article</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p>Achieving cybersecurity throughout the product life cycle requires organizational and technological changes. The organizational component involves clear responsibility for cybersecurity in the product and production environment. A few companies have acted by giving the chief information security officer (CISO) responsibility for cybersecurity in both information technology (IT) and operating technology (OT). Whatever the structural setup, aligning on goals is crucial, since there must be strong collaboration among the CISO function and other departments, be it product development, production, or even customer service. Additionally, new roles should be created that systematically integrate security into all relevant products and processes. A European telco and media company, for example, is leveraging large-scale training programs to create a community of “security champions” throughout the organization. These security champions get additional decision-making authority within their teams as a result of achieving “cybersecurity capable” status. The company’s CISO organization has used these trainings to grow its reach by a factor of four.</p>
<h3>5. Be rigorous in transforming mind-sets and skills</h3>
<p>Institutionalizing the notion that security is everyone’s business starts at the top. Executives should role model security behavior and cultivate a culture where security is constantly evolving and where people are rewarded, not punished, for identifying weak spots.</p>
<p>Additionally, CEOs need to ensure that security-specific knowledge and qualifications become a standard requirement for employees in IT, product development, and production. On the one hand, additional training programs for current employees may help; on the other, specific IoT security talent needs to be developed. Cybersecurity specialists must understand product development and production as well as IT security. To develop these crossover skills at scale, companies should consider working with other players in the industry, for example, to create university programs and vocational training curricula.</p>
<h3>6. Create a point-of-contact system for external security researchers and implement a postbreach response plan</h3>
<p>Companies need to implement a single, visible point of contact for IoT-security-related notifications or complaints. In the past two years, and especially in the IoT context, there have been numerous examples of security researchers trying to notify a company several times after discovering a breach and the company either not following up at all, or the researcher being handed from one department to the next without anyone taking responsibility for the matter.</p>
<p>In addition, companies need a response plan in place for different attack scenarios. The fallout from an unprofessional response to an incident is often more damaging than the incident itself. In an IoT world, incidents can affect the heart of a company’s operations, so cybersecurity needs to be part of business continuity management and disaster-recovery planning. Maybe most important, organizations must design a strong communication strategy that is scenario specific and delivers current, transparent, and appropriate messaging to customers, regulators, investors—and potentially the general public.</p>
<hr>
<p>Cybersecurity remains much talked about, but it’s not yet used as a differentiating factor on the business side. With the advent of the Internet of Things, there’s an opportunity to move ahead and designate the security of products, production processes, and platforms as a strategic priority. The breadth of the challenge spans the entire supply chain and the whole product life cycle and includes both the regulatory and the communication strategy. For CEOs in IoT organizations, we believe cybersecurity should be at the top of the agenda until rigorous processes are in place, resilience is established, and mind-sets are transformed.</p>

id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"Six ways CEOs can promote cybersecurity in the IoT age","displayName":"Six ways CEOs can promote cybersecurity in the IoT age","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"c78f6f0d-a14f-426a-8b54-44410720568a","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Six ways CEOs can promote cybersecurity in the IoT age"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":""},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Billions of devices are being brought online as the Internet of Things develops, creating new vulnerabilities. Here\u0026rsquo;s how leaders can regain control."}},"sEODescription":{"value":""},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2017-08-31T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAs digitization has risen\u003c/strong\u003e on the executive agenda, cybersecurity skills and processes in most companies have also advanced, though at a slower pace. But \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/the-internet-of-things-the-value-of-digitizing-the-physical-world\"\u003erapid growth in the Internet of Things\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;(IoT) is changing the game. Cybersecurity is more relevant and challenging than ever, and companies need to build capabilities in this area\u0026mdash;quickly.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[DisruptorSignUp left]]\n\u003cp\u003eIoT holds great potential to help companies improve their products and services or increase production efficiency by harnessing sensors and actuators that seamlessly connect objects to computing systems. No wonder, then, that many companies are bringing more and more devices, products, or production systems online. Conventional estimates suggest we could reach 20 billion to 30 billion connected devices globally by 2020, up from 10 billion to 15 billion devices in 2015. However, as devices proliferate, the security risks will increase sharply. Historically, risking the confidentiality and integrity of information was the prime concern compared with any risk regarding availability. In the IoT world, lack of availability of key plants or\u0026mdash;even worse\u0026mdash;tampering with a customer product becomes the dominating risk. How can CEOs and senior executives hedge against that threat?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe challenge of cybersecurity in the Internet of Things\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith the IoT, security challenges move from a company\u0026rsquo;s traditional IT infrastructure into its connected products in the field. And these challenges remain an issue through the entire product life cycle, long after products have been sold. What\u0026rsquo;s more, industrial IoT, or Industry 4.0, means that security becomes \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/how-to-achieve-and-sustain-the-impact-of-digital-manufacturing-at-scale\"\u003ea pervasive issue in production\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;as well. Cyberthreats in the world of IoT can have consequences beyond compromised customer privacy. Critical equipment, such as pacemakers and entire manufacturing plants, is now vulnerable\u0026mdash;meaning that customer health and a company\u0026rsquo;s total production capability are at risk.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe sheer number of cybersecurity attack vectors increases dramatically as ever more \u0026ldquo;things\u0026rdquo; are connected. Earlier, a large corporate network might have somewhere between 50,000 and 500,000 endpoints; with the IoT, we are talking about millions or tens of millions of endpoints. Unfortunately, many of these consist of legacy devices with inadequate security, or no security at all.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis added complexity makes the IoT a more difficult security environment for companies to manage. Those that succeed, though, could use strong cybersecurity to differentiate themselves in many industries.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo explore views on the relevance of and companies\u0026rsquo; preparedness for IoT security, McKinsey conducted a multinational expert survey with 400 managers from Germany, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States. The results indicate a yawning gap between perceived priority and the level of preparedness:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul class=\"bulletList\"\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eOf the IoT-involved experts surveyed, 75 percent say that IoT security is either important or very important, and that its relevance will increase. But only 16 percent say their company is well prepared for the challenge (Exhibit 1). The survey also indicated that low preparedness is often linked to insufficient budget allocated to IoT cybersecurity.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eOur interviews revealed that companies are ill prepared at every step of the IoT security action chain (predict, prevent, detect, react). Especially weak are prediction capabilities; 16 percent feel well prepared, compared with 24 to 28 percent on prevent, detect, and react.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMore than one-third of companies lack a cybersecurity strategy that also covers the IoT. The rest have some sort of strategy but many report struggling to implement it.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eWhy haven\u0026rsquo;t companies made progress on cybersecurity implementation, given the perceived risk? Our survey indicated a few factors:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul class=\"bulletList\"\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eLack of prioritization.\u003c/em\u003e In general, there isn\u0026rsquo;t an \u0026ldquo;act now\u0026rdquo; mentality among senior management. Few leaders have made the business case for a specific IoT security strategy that would, in turn, make the effort a priority and trigger the allocation of sufficient resources.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eUnclear responsibility.\u003c/em\u003e There needs to be a holistic cybersecurity concept for the entire IoT stack, but often no single player feels responsible for creating it. First, there is the question of whether initial responsibility lies with product makers or with suppliers. And within organizations, it\u0026rsquo;s proved difficult to determine which unit (IT security, production, product development, or customer service) should take the lead. Product or plant managers often do not have cybersecurity expertise, while corporate IT does not have sufficient access to product teams or the industrial control systems \u0026ldquo;behind the fence.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eLack of standards and technical skills.\u003c/em\u003e There are some industry working groups, but IoT security standards are still largely nonexistent. Even if there were standards in place, the technical competence to implement them\u0026mdash;a mix of operational technology and IT security knowledge\u0026mdash;is in short supply.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n[[disruptor1UP dis1]]\n\u003cp\u003eWith the advent of the IoT, cybersecurity affects the entire business model. Adequately addressing the threat means bringing together several business perspectives, including the market, the customer, production, and IT. And the CEO is often the only leader with the authority to make cybersecurity a priority across all these areas.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eSix recommendations for CEOs\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough there is no single winning approach for tackling \u003ca href=\"/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/cybersecurity-for-the-iot-how-trust-can-unlock-value\"\u003ecybersecurity in the IoT\u003c/a\u003e, six recommendations can guide senior executives. Three concern strategic lenses for thinking about IoT security, and the other three are actions to help CEOs and other leaders set their organizations up for success.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e1. Understand what IoT security will mean for your industry and business model\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAcross all industries, a certain minimum level of IoT security will be required as a matter of \u0026ldquo;hygiene.\u0026rdquo; The recent WannaCry attack largely compromised organizations with legacy operating systems that had not been patched appropriately. Simple patch management\u0026mdash;a matter of adequate IT management, not sophisticated cyberdefense\u0026mdash;should be routine, not something customers pay a price premium for.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, we think there is potential for treating security as more than just hygiene. In the past decade, many companies saw IT evolve from a cost center to a source of real differentiation, driving customer satisfaction and willingness to pay. A similar change could lie ahead for IoT security, and in an increasing number of industries, we are already witnessing it today. One example is the physical security industry. Door-lock companies can already today demand a price premium for products with especially strong cybersecurity features, as cybersecurity can make or break the main function of the product.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEffective IoT security solutions consider an organization\u0026rsquo;s business model, where it lies in the value chain, and the industry structures in which it operates (see sidebar, \u0026ldquo;More trust, less downtime: Examples of the role and relevance of IoT security by industry\u0026rdquo;).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[sidebar sidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003eCEOs must understand the role and relevance of IoT security in their industries and how to monetize solutions in alignment with their business model. A thorough understanding of what IoT security means for a company cannot end at the strategic level, though. CEOs need to be aware of the main points of vulnerability. Typically, an overview of the top attack scenarios for a specific company and an understanding of attackers and their motivations will be a good base for further strategy development and budget allocations. Security investments must be targeted according to the risk most detrimental to the specific business or industry.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e2. Set up clear roles and responsibilities for IoT security along your supply chain\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIoT requires a holistic cybersecurity concept that extends across the entire IoT stack\u0026mdash;all layers of the application, communication, and sensors. Of course, each layer needs to be secured, but companies also need to prepare for cross-layer threats (Exhibit 2).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eThis will require a strategic dialogue with upstream and downstream business partners, whether suppliers or customers, to sort out responsibilities for security along the entire supply chain. A starting point for this discussion should be identifying the weakest links in the holistic model; from an attacker\u0026rsquo;s point of view, these will be targeted first to harm the entire chain. Who then takes on which role should depend on who has the competence and who has the incentives, which might include a monetization model. Industry players active in each part of the IoT stack bring certain advantages they can build on to provide an integrated solution:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul class=\"bulletList\"\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eDevice and \u003ca href=\"/industries/semiconductors/our-insights/security-in-the-internet-of-things\"\u003esemiconductor manufacturers\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;active at the lower level of the stack can build on their design capabilities of low-level (hardware) security as an advantage for designing higher (software) security.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eNetwork equipment manufacturers profit from the fact that many key competencies in transport-layer security design are applicable to the application layer. Beyond that, they can build on their hardware design capabilities to offer an integrated solution.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eApplication designers can leverage their control of application interfaces or customer access as an advantage in defining low-level architectures.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e3. Engage in strategic conversations with your regulator and collaborate with other industry players\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA company\u0026rsquo;s cybersecurity creates externalities that go far beyond the effects on the company\u0026rsquo;s performance itself and thus needs to be tackled across the classic government\u0026ndash;business divide. Most current cybersecurity standards fall short because they are neither industry specific nor detailed enough, and they neglect most layers of the IoT stack, including production and product development. Regulators will eventually step in to address this gap, and companies need to get involved in the discussion, or set the tone.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIndustry leaders can shape these structures by bringing together key players to establish IoT security standards for their industry. Partnerships with other players, including competitors, can also lead to a mutually beneficial pooling of resources beyond official industry standards. In the banking sector, for instance, one company got several competitors together to set up \u0026ldquo;shared assessments\u0026rdquo; to evaluate security technology vendors, resulting in enormous efficiency gains for both the banks and their suppliers. Another example from the sector is FS-ISAC, an information community through which competing banks share information on security weaknesses, attacks, and successful countermeasures.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e4. Conceive of cybersecurity as a priority for the entire product life cycle, and develop relevant skills to achieve it\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSecurity needs to be part of the entire product life cycle, from product design to the development process, and continuing each day of the product\u0026rsquo;s use. Fundamental to the security of products in the field is \u0026ldquo;security by design\u0026rdquo; in the product-development stage. It\u0026rsquo;s also crucial to ensure security during the production or manufacturing process, given the role of Industry 4.0 in driving the proliferation of IoT on shop floors and in other production settings. Last, a concept is required for securing products after they have been sold. To this end, companies need a strategy to deliver security patches to products in the field, for example, via over-the-air update capabilities.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[disruptor1UP dis2]]\n\u003cp\u003eAchieving cybersecurity throughout the product life cycle requires organizational and technological changes. The organizational component involves clear responsibility for cybersecurity in the product and production environment. A few companies have acted by giving the chief information security officer (CISO) responsibility for cybersecurity in both information technology (IT) and operating technology (OT). Whatever the structural setup, aligning on goals is crucial, since there must be strong collaboration among the CISO function and other departments, be it product development, production, or even customer service. Additionally, new roles should be created that systematically integrate security into all relevant products and processes. A European telco and media company, for example, is leveraging large-scale training programs to create a community of \u0026ldquo;security champions\u0026rdquo; throughout the organization. These security champions get additional decision-making authority within their teams as a result of achieving \u0026ldquo;cybersecurity capable\u0026rdquo; status. The company\u0026rsquo;s CISO organization has used these trainings to grow its reach by a factor of four.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e5. Be rigorous in transforming mind-sets and skills\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInstitutionalizing the notion that security is everyone\u0026rsquo;s business starts at the top. Executives should role model security behavior and cultivate a culture where security is constantly evolving and where people are rewarded, not punished, for identifying weak spots.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAdditionally, CEOs need to ensure that security-specific knowledge and qualifications become a standard requirement for employees in IT, product development, and production. On the one hand, additional training programs for current employees may help; on the other, specific IoT security talent needs to be developed. Cybersecurity specialists must understand product development and production as well as IT security. To develop these crossover skills at scale, companies should consider working with other players in the industry, for example, to create university programs and vocational training curricula.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e6. Create a point-of-contact system for external security researchers and implement a postbreach response plan\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCompanies need to implement a single, visible point of contact for IoT-security-related notifications or complaints. In the past two years, and especially in the IoT context, there have been numerous examples of security researchers trying to notify a company several times after discovering a breach and the company either not following up at all, or the researcher being handed from one department to the next without anyone taking responsibility for the matter.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn addition, companies need a response plan in place for different attack scenarios. The fallout from an unprofessional response to an incident is often more damaging than the incident itself. In an IoT world, incidents can affect the heart of a company\u0026rsquo;s operations, so cybersecurity needs to be part of business continuity management and disaster-recovery planning. Maybe most important, organizations must design a strong communication strategy that is scenario specific and delivers current, transparent, and appropriate messaging to customers, regulators, investors\u0026mdash;and potentially the general public.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCybersecurity remains much talked about, but it\u0026rsquo;s not yet used as a differentiating factor on the business side. With the advent of the Internet of Things, there\u0026rsquo;s an opportunity to move ahead and designate the security of products, production processes, and platforms as a strategic priority. The breadth of the challenge spans the entire supply chain and the whole product life cycle and includes both the regulatory and the communication strategy. For CEOs in IoT organizations, we believe cybersecurity should be at the top of the agenda until rigorous processes are in place, resilience is established, and mind-sets are transformed.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[DisruptorSignUp strategy varies by industry and company type. Industries differ in their approach, depending on many factors, such as the role of cybersecurity in differentiating the product, the supply-chain structure and incentives, and the level of maturity reached to date. A few examples illustrate this:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul class=\"bulletList\"\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eFor an energy utility, IoT security is mostly a production play, as it will mean dealing with a large installed base of legacy production systems that were never designed to be connected and, in turn, were not designed with defense against cyberattacks in mind. What is more, legacy systems have little additional capacity (for example, computing performance and memory) that could be used for added security measures, and they are often not accessible in the field. To reap the huge benefits from connecting these systems nonetheless, targeted countermeasures need to be taken. Process-industry players in particular have leveraged their innate strength in industrial safety for creating new processes and safety measures, creating redundancy, and \u0026ldquo;sandboxing\u0026rdquo; key systems to avoid entire system failure. Challenges for industrials lie in the lack of cybersecurity expertise of many component suppliers and the lack of standardization incentives for many integrators.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eFor \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/shifting-gears-in-cybersecurity-for-connected-cars\"\u003eautomotive OEMs\u003c/a\u003e, IoT security is also a product play and will become the new quality management for the era of connected cars. OEMs are facing unique challenges given the increasing complexity of their product: a modern car includes between 30 and 100 electronic control units (ECUs) and hundreds of millions lines of code\u0026mdash;a level of complexity at which even the best programmers cannot avoid vulnerabilities. What\u0026rsquo;s more, the automotive industry has one of the most fragmented supply chains. The 30 to 100 ECUs could easily be sourced from more than 20 different suppliers, creating additional complexity. Thus, a holistic concept is needed to address two aspects. First, cybersecurity needs to be embedded in the design and development of the product, as well as in the maintenance and response architecture. Second, OEMs must work closely in their ecosystem\u0026mdash;for example, with other industry players and regulatory bodies to set up standards, and with the end users who are directly involved in protecting their cars (such as by keeping software updated). However, solutions will have to scale well and be cost effective, as OEMs have to contend with users\u0026rsquo; limited willingness to pay for added cybersecurity.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"More trust, less downtime: Examples of the role and relevance of IoT
